tutorial.title: Album Release Page
tutorial.descriptionContent: Learn how to use Flexbox to create a dynamic webpage for an up-and-coming band

executableContent.instructions:
Let's use our CSS knowledge to style an album release page.  We'll use CSS Flexbox to dynamically style the page for multiple screen sizes.

To build the album release page, we'll set up two Flexbox containers: one to house the album artwork, metadata, and description, and another for the song list. Let's start setting up the first `<div>`. 

1. Set the ID of the first `<div>` element in the body tag to `"album"`.

executableContent.instructions:
Next, we'll want the album information to wrap if the screen gets too narrow to fit all of the album metadata. This should clean up the site's formatting significantly.

If you want to see how the property changes the layout, run the code first and then run it again after doing the task.

1. Set the `flex-wrap` property on the `#album` element so that the items wrap when they don't fit on screen.

executableContent.instructions:
We want the album description to sit to the right of the album metadata when the screen is wide enough. We can achieve this by establishing a default width and then specifying how much or how little the elements can grow or shrink. 

To see Flexbox in action, try increasing and decreasing the window size before and after completing the tasks.

1. Inside the `#description` selector, set flex basis to a default width of `250px`.
2. Set flex grow so that the element automatically grows. 
3. Set flex shrink so that the element does not automatically shrink.

executableContent.instructions:
The last element in the `#songlist` represents 15 bonus tracks. We want this item to appear larger in the list, and grow to fill any remaining space. 

To do that, we'll add an additional CSS class called `bonus` to the last element in the song list and use flexbox to make it grow.

1. Inside `index.html`, find the last element that has `+15 bonus tracks` as text. Add an additional class name called `"bonus"` to the element.
2. Inside `style.css`, create a `.bonus` selector and use Flexbox to make the flex item grow.
